Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Lithic Minimalization And Ecological Risk

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project evaluates the role of climatic variability in the evolution of small tool technologies. Small tool technologies are a novel and cyclical feature in Homo sapiens societies. Nanotechnologies such as have revolutionized biomedical sciences, engineering and computer systems are now considered hallmarks of the "digital age." Yet, the practice of producing small tools emerged in African and Eurasia over 100 000 years ago. These tools are known as microliths. Archaeologists link microliths to such distinctive human behaviors as the production of composite tools (e.g. projectile weapons), the construction of ecological niches, extensive social networking, and global human dispersals. Anthropologists have long recognized a link between microlithic technologies and ecological risk, or the frequency and severity of economic loss due to insufficient recovery of energy from their environment. Long-term comparative research on processes of toolkit microlithization as a response to ecological risk is hampered by variable definitions for microliths; uncertainty about how microliths were made; and a lack of data on how microlith production methods were culturally transmitted.

This project will use a comparative technological approach to the rich southern African MIS 2 (c. 29 - 12 ka) archaeological record to address these obstacles. First, it will establish statistical guidelines for defining microliths to overcome their variable definitions. Second, it will obtain detailed technological information from experiments on siliceous rocks and quartz minerals to compare two primary microlith production strategies: bipolar and freehand reduction. Third, it will track evidence for the cultural transmission of these production strategies using attributes of core modification and flake morphology to indicate lithic process vs. product copying. Technological data will be combined with modern climatic, paleoenvironmental and spatial data to assess the role of ecological risk in the uptake and spread of microlithic technologies in southern Africa. These relationship will be assessed on stone tools at three southern African rockshelters: Sehonghong, Ntloana T'oana and Boomplaas. The southern African MIS 2 archaeological record is uniquely positioned to offer insights into the operation of analogous microlithic technological systems in other areas of the world, and thus human behavioral evolution more broadly. Rapid climate change is a concern shared by all of humanity past and present. Although the role of climate change in our future is yet to be determined, how our late Pleistocene ancestors dealt with climate change is a story written in stone. Our future survival depends on understanding this story.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Miniaturization, the systematic production and use of small technologies, is a widespread and pervasive phenomenon in contemporary technology. Only three decades ago launching a satellite into space required room-sized computers. Now, the computational power necessary to perform such a task come standard on devices that fit in the palm of one’s hand.

Lithic miniaturization, the production of small stone tools from small cores, is the longest, most enduring and arguably the most consequential example of prehistoric technological miniaturization. Small stone tools occur sporadically throughout the archaeological record, but they became an essential feature of late Pleistocene (c. < 250 000 years) lithic technology across southern Africa.

Archaeological approaches have reduced the perceived technological variability in processes of lithic miniaturization and have limited our ability to study the strategic costs and benefits of different forms of lithic miniaturization. This dissertation combines experimental and archaeological approaches to explore variability in lithic miniaturization and to explain the proximate and ultimate causes for these processes c. 40 – 12 kcal BP at two rock-shelters, Sehonghong (Lesotho) and Boomplaas (South Africa).

The project’s experiments provide the first data on the costs and benefits of bipolar and freehand reduction as lithic miniaturization strategies for quartz and flint. They show the relative benefits of bipolar reduction over freehand reduction and other more derived strategies in terms of raw material economy and reduction efficiency. The experimental data overturn long-held assumptions about the costs of lithic miniaturization. The experiments also provide clear, reproducible, and probabilistic frameworks for identifying bipolar reduction in archaeological assemblages.

The project’s archaeological data illustrate the use of the SUMMs approach to identifying intentionality in prehistoric lithic miniaturization processes. At both study sites, this dissertation finds evidence for the following:

- Prehistoric toolmakers varied their use of bipolar reduction strategically in response to raw material constraints, reduction efficiency, and the size of lithic reduction.

- Lithic miniaturization processes were strategically organized to produce: bladelets, small flakes, and microliths (small retouched tools). These three small tool ‘types’ do not co-vary in parallel with one another.

- Core and flake scar patterns shifted from radial and sub-radial to bidirectional and unidirectional as size decreased.

- Core management and flake wear patterns show distinct modalities in relation to flake size and raw material types.

- Patterns of size variation and technological organization vary in relation to raw material variability.

This project’s final component tested hypotheses about occupation intensity and paleoenvironmental variability’s effects on the structure and organization of lithic miniaturization processes. Site occupation intensity shows a strong correlation with processes of lithic miniaturization at Boomplaas, but not at Sehonghong. The lack of correlation at Sehonghong may be the result of unresolved issues in the dating of its LGM occupation(s). At Boomplaas, members with the highest occupation intensities showed high bipolar frequencies, low minimally-worked nodule frequencies, low core masses, and low retouch frequencies. These patterns match predictions from research on hunter-gatherer mobility and the organization of technology.

At Boomplaas, the project finds strong evidence for shifts in technology correlated with shifts in paleoenvironmental conditions. Terminal Pleistocene aridity signals coincide with a period of major change in the organization of lithic miniaturization and occupation intensity. Assemblages deposited during warmer and more arid periods with greater C4 grasslands show greater degrees of miniaturization (smaller cores, smaller flakes), increased bipolar reduction, bladelet production, and reduced raw material stockpiles. These patterns coincide with post-glacial sea-level rise and large-scale social and ecological changes across the southern Cape. The data suggest the in South Africa, terminal Pleistocene conditions, not the LGM, drove humans to reorganize lithic miniaturization strategies.

This project’s approach to lithic miniaturization marks a break with historical practices in LSA archaeology and Pleistocene archaeology in general. It joins a relatively new wave of research focused on modeling the strategic costs and benefits of technology (e.g., Torrence, 1989). That is, it treats lithic technology as a complex system with multiple, mutually interacting components that respond dynamically to external and internal forces.

In the case of late Pleistocene southern Africa, rather than going big, toolmakers ‘went small,’ and adapted lithic miniaturization to their subsistence, settlement, and social strategies in complex and variable ways that transcend traditional Industries, Ages, or Stages. By recourse to lithic miniaturization southern African hunter-gatherers survived and thrived, resisting incursions by agro-pastoralists far longer than in any but a handful of locations in Africa.

This study developed a framework for predictive modeling lithic miniaturization’s variation and strategic and enduring deployment by prehistoric humans. Doing this steps away from traditional approaches to southern Africa’s late Pleistocene lithic evidence. One hopes it is in the right direction. Only time and further testing of its hypotheses with newly-discovered evidence about lithic miniaturization will tell if it a step forward towards better understanding behavioral variability in southern African prehistory.
